I.3 Proposition 3.3

Published

05 October 2021

Problem

Let $f: X \to Y$, $g: Y \to U$, and $h: U \to V$ be functions. Then, the compositions $(h \circ g) \circ f$ and $h \circ (g \circ f): X \to V$ are well-defined and $(h \circ g) \circ f = h \circ (g \circ f)$ (associativity of composition).

Solution

Lemma I: $(h \circ g) \circ f$ is well-defined map from $X$ to $V$

Proof:

Since $g: Y \to U$ and $h: U \to V$, $h \circ g: Y \to V$ by definition of composition. Further, since $f: X \to Y$, we have $(h \circ g) \circ f: X \to V$ by the same definition.


Lemma II: $h \circ (g \circ f)$ is well-defined map from $X$ to $V$

Proof:

Since $f: X \to Y$ and $g: Y \to U$, $g \circ f: X \to U$ by definition of composition. Further, since $h: U \to V$, we have $h \circ (g \circ f): X \to V$ by the same definition.


We now show that composition is associative, i.e. that $(h \circ g) \circ f = h \circ (g \circ f)$. Recall that in order to show that two functions are equal, we must show that they have the same domain, codomain, and “rule”. By the previous lemmas, we know that both $(h \circ g) \circ f$ and $h \circ (g \circ f)$ have the same domain ($X$) and codomain ($V$), so all that remains is the rule.

For this, let $x$ be an arbitrary element of $X$. Then,

$$ \begin{alignat}{2} ((h \circ g) \circ f)(x) &= (h \circ g)(f(x)) &&\text{ (by defn. of composition)} \\ &= h(g(f(x))) &&\text{ (by defn. of composition)} \\ &= h((g \circ f(x)) &&\text{ (by defn. of composition)} \\ &= (h(g \circ f))(x) &&\text{ (by defn. of composition)} \end{alignat} $$

Thus, the rule is also the same and the two functions are equal.
